4.title: Sleep
dlg:
If you have to take over-the-counter sleep aids for more than 5 nights in a row, then it is time to talk to a doctor.
Often, lack of sleep is the symptom that would make someone with depression who doesn't know to seek medical help.

(Discuss sleep apnea) Central sleep apnea consists of repeated episodes of breathing cessation or shallow breathing during sleep, lasting at least 10 sec, caused by diminished respiratory effort. The disorder typically manifests as insomnia or as disturbed and unrefreshing sleep.

Obstructive sleep apnea consists of episodes of partial or complete closure of the upper airway during sleep, leading to cessation of breathing for > 10 sec. Sometimes patients awaken, gasping. These episodes disrupt sleep and result in a feeling of unrefreshing sleep and EDS

Sleep maintenance insomnia suggests advanced sleep phase syndrome, major depression, central or obstructive sleep apnea, periodic limb movement disorder, or aging. In patients with significant snoring, frequent awakenings, and other risk factors, obstructive sleep apnea is quite likely.

0.header:
This assumes you are having difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep through the night.

Let's see what can get you some sleep that is available over the counter.

1.header: Is it that you can't fall asleep on most nights?

3.header: Do you keep waking up during sleep?

4.header:
Yes?
Hope you are not looking at sleep apnea.
(See 'FYI' for a brief intro to sleep apnea)

5.header: Do you wake up earlier than you want to?

6.header:
Earlier?
Anyway, it depends on how you feel when you wake up.

If you wake up feeling refreshed, you are getting enough sleep. For some people, this may take only 4 hours. Others may need up to 10 hours to feel rested.

Let's Continue.

7.header: Do you feel refreshed on waking up?

9.header: What about feeling tired during the day due to too little sleep?

11.header: Has this been going on for a while or just started?

12.header:
A while?
You should be seeing a doctor on this one.

Lack of sleep is a key symptom of depression, you should be checked for depression if you are having trouble sleeping.

See a dcotor if your sleeping problem occur more than 3 nights per week for more than 1 month

Let's continue to see what a pharmacist think would work for you over-the-counter until you can see a doctor for an evaluation if you are not at the moment.

13.header:
Just starting?
Sometimes good sleep hygiene is all you need if your sleeplessness is just starting.

Meanwhile, let's continue and see what can get you some sleep that is available over-the-counter if you are using good sleeping habits.

20.header: Which of the poor sleeping habits below apply to you?

options.title: Spends too much time in bed while awake
Talk a lot on the phone while in bed

20.except: Oops!,You told me nothing

21.header:
None of these?
Just a few more questions for you.

22.header:
It is important you get rid of this poor sleep habit.

You should use the bed only for sleep. Consider it a place where you want to rest your head for the day.

30.header:
What about medications?
Which of these did you take lately?
30.except: Oops!, You told me nothing

31.header:
Nothing?
Great. Some medications can cause lack of sleep. Let's continue.

32.header:
Not listed?
Some medications can cause lack of sleep. Check the side effects.

33.header: Some medications can cause lack of sleep. The list include these medications.

40.header:
Physical, social, and mental health issues can affect sleep patterns.

Which of these apply to you?
40.except: Oops!,You told me nothing

41.header:
None of these?
Anyway, have you tried something yet?

42.header:
This can affect your sleep. Hope you are getting some medical help for these.

Tried something yet?

50.header:
Nothing yet?
Oh well, let's see what a pharmacist recommend for sleep that is available over-the-counter.

Or would you like to see the nearest urgent care clinic to you?

60.header:
What have you tried so far?
Here are what we think below.
60.except:
What have you tried so far?
Here are what we think below.

61.header:
None of these?
Alright, let's see what a pharmacist recommend you take over-the-counter.

Just to remind you that over-the-counter sleep aids are for occasional use like if your menstrual period is here or if you have a big day tomorrow and you want to sleep good and so on.

If sleep problems persists, let your doctor know. It may be a sign of something serious.

62.header:
Prescription sleep aid?
You may want to check with the doctor if it is not working.

If you ran out of the prescription and would like to see what a pharmacist recommend over-the-counter, let's continue.

Just to remind you that over-the-counter sleep aids are for occasional use like if your menstrual period is here or if you have a big day tomorrow and you want to sleep good and so on.

If sleep problems persists, let your doctor know. It may be a sign of something serious.

63.header:
Let's see what a pharmacist recommend you use over-the-counter.

Just to remind you that over-the-counter sleep aids are for occasional use like if your menstrual period is here or if you have a big day tomorrow and you want to sleep good.

If sleep problems persists, let your doctor know. It may be a sign of something serious.

5.title: Hair Loss
dlg:
In female pattern baldness:
Hair thins mainly on the top and crown of the scalp. It usually starts with a widening through the center hair part. The front hairline remains. The hair loss rarely progresses to total or near total baldness, as it may in men

It may be related to Aging, Changes in the levels of androgens (male hormones).

For example, after reaching menopause, many women find that the hair on their head is thinner, while the hair on their face is coarser and Family history of male or female pattern baldness

0.header:
Hair loss
could be temporary or permanent depending on the cause.

Some cases could be medical and require a doctor's office visit to determine the cause of the hair loss, whereas others are hereditary or due to medications.

Men and women might loose hair for different reasons.

Let's see what a pharmacist recommend over the counter for hair loss.

1.header: Who are we talking about here?

2.header:
Male pattern hair loss is the most common type of hair loss in men.

Let's see if this is the case here.

If not, we can try to determine what may be causing it.

10.header: Is the hairline gradually moving backward?

12.header:
Is it becoming finer or thinner?

Or shorter?

14.header: Is the hair loss forming an "M" shape?

15.header:
Yes?
You may be looking at a pattern of male balding or hair loss.

Let's continue and see what else we have.

16.header: Has it formed a "U" shape?

17.header:
Yes?
Looking at a pattern of male hair loss.

Continue discussion on male pattern hair loss

18.header: Do you have a family history of hair loss?

19.header:
Yes?
Male pattern hair loss is an androgen-dependent hereditary disorder.

Dihydrotestosterone plays a major role.

20.header:
A quick review of where we are so far.

If your answer is 'Yes' so far and no family history of hair loss, you might want to rule out causes due to drugs.

If you've answered 'No' so far, then your hair loss is not due to a pattern of baldness associated with men. It might be due to other reasons for which you will have to see a doctor for further evaluation.

Let's have an idea of what may be going on. We will start with medications.

30.header:
Did you start taking any of the group of drugs listed below?

Within the last 3 months?

-Chemo agents
-Warfarin, Heparin
-ACE inhibitors
-β-blockers
-antithyroid drugs
anticonvulsants
vitamin A excess
Accutane

--lithium
-Gemfibrozil, Clofibrate
-Amphetamines
-Allopurinol
-Testosterone
-NSAIDS
-Methotrexate
-Cimetidine, ranitidine

31.header:
Yes?
Discuss your hair loss with your doctor.

These drugs can

32.header: Did you have a major blood loss within the past 3 or 4 months?

34.header: What about a major surgery?

35.header:
Yes?
This may be the cause of your hair loss.

We think you might have a major number of your hair entering the resting phase.

36.header: Anything like a very high fever within the past 3 months or so?

37.header:
Yes?
This can cause a large number of your hair to enter the resting phase.

38.header:
Is the skin on your scalp under the hairloss area red, scaly or itchy?

Or looking abnormal?

39.header:
Seek urgent care or call the doctor.

Here is why:

  • Might be looking at ringworm of the scalp
  • Might be looking at lupus

40.header:
Is it patchy?

Or moth-eaten in appearance?

41.header:
Seek urgent care or call the doctor.

Here is why:

  • Might be looking at secondary syphilis

42.header: Are you suddenly experiencing circular, smooth patches of hair loss?

44.header:
What about exclamation point hairs at edges of bald patches?

Or Short, broken hairs?

45.header:
Seek doctor office visit.

Here is why:

  • May be looking at alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is thought to be an autoimmune condition. This occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys healthy body tissue.

46.header:
If the questions so far does not fit your profile...

...discuss this hair loss with your doctor.

There are other causes of hair loss. To name a few:

  • Stress
  • Thyroid disorders
  • Heavy metal poisoning (boric acid, mercury, thallium)
  • Nutritional deficiencies
  • Nervous habits such as scalp rubbing
  • Excessive shampooing and blow-drying
  • Tumor of adrenal glands
  • Lichen planus of the scalp.

Note:
The hair loss that can be taken care of is mainly that due to male pattern baldness. For most others, it is advised you see a doctor and discuss the underlying cause of the hair loss.

Let's see what a pharmacist recommend over the counter for male pattern hair loss.

50.header:
Let's see if you are looking at female pattern hair loss.

If not, we will take a look at other things that may be causing this hair loss.

51.header: Would you say your hair is thinning mainly on the top and crown of the scalp?

53.header: Is the center part widening?

54.header:
It is?
We are beginning to think female pattern balding going on here.
